meta.title: From HARD to BOILED
meta.author: Sandy Weisz and Mao Reynolds
meta.message: This week’s Raddles unpack common tropes in crime fiction. This sense of “hardboiled,” meaning “severe” or “tough,” dates to at least 1886, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. Cynical, unemotional protagonists dominated the wave of hardboiled pulp novels in the 1930s.
